Buy This Book Part II In my quest to keep myself entertained at work I often stumble upon things that are too good to keep to myself. "A Year At The Movies" by Kevin Murphy is my most recent find. Murphy, better known as Tom Servo from MST3K, has set out to see one movie a day (in a theater or public venue) for an entire year. Now I know that this may seem like a dusty book on film criticism... but it ain't. The tag-line for the book is "One Man's Filmgoing Odyssey and it is indeed that. Murphy is truly in love with the movie going expierence and it shows. If you hate multiplexes or Hollywood crap (cough*Matrix*cough) this is a book you should read. Next in Eric's Book Club is "Mike Nelson's Death Rat!" We'll see how that one goes. In other crap related news: I read that The Matrix isn't doing as well as the suits had hoped. Boo-hoo. If you have the time hop on over to aintitcoolnews.com and read the review posted there. Harry Knowles (who I think wrote the review) writes in circles trying to justify to himself that it was a good movie. The review is typically long-winded and his complaints are backed up by lame praise in an attempt to cancel them out. It's like five years ago when I was trying to stick up for The Phantom Menace. "Well...The lightsaber duel at the end made it all worth while!" What can I say some folks just like stupid movies.

I've come back to tell you about... THE WORST MOVIE...EVER! Okay, I've been a bit busy as of late so let's get to it. Before I begin a short quote from Mike Nelson's book 'Movie Megacheese.' If you don't have it, buy it. "We live in a world that has laid untold riches at the feet of Keanu Reeves as reward for his ability to say the word 'whoa.'" Now onto the good stuff. The Matrix Reloaded is not simply the worst movie ever. It is the worst THING ever. Never before have I encountered a movie with such obvious contempt for its audience. You hate the movie and it hates you right back. It's a little known fact that if all the slow-motion in the Matrix was shown at regular speed the movie is cut down from a robust 138 min. to a mere 27 min. 38 sec. Seriously, the movie starts with a slo-mo motorcycle crash jumps to a slo-mo back-flip and meanders into a(nother) slo-mo fall out a window, guns-a-blazin'. But it was all a dream. At this point the movie begins an hour of long and pointless expostion. They return to a place that's not the Matrix and is populated buy hippies and their drum circles. Vague references are made to a nebulous back story not covered by the first movie. They can be filled in by cartoons and video games and if you haven't bought them now... you're less of a person. So after the explanation of nothing (everyone speaks in euphemisms or riddles) they go back to the Matrix to look for...stuff. But not before an artfully shot hippie party/love scene. So, let me get this straight, evil machines have banished humanity from the face of the planet and the 'rave' culture survives? Great. I hope I was one of the first killed when they took over. In the Matrix more vague statements are made and slo-mo fight scenes are had. Every frame of which is slowed down, showing the violence in a new and (almost) pornographic light. Don't get me wrong. I love violence and I love pornography, but in the case of the Matrix it's a long way from chocolate in peanut butter. The special effects in this movie caused me to look a bit more closely at the term. When they say special they mean "special." As in "Missing a chromosome or three." One of the things I like about the medium of film is the suspension of disbelief aspect. When somebody is replaced with a 'digital double' you know. The computer's movements seem even more blocky and wooden than those of the real actors. Which brings me to the stars of the movie. All actors involved were more than likely shot-up with barbiturates or reading thier lines from cue cards held off camera. People (well, alright, me) say jokingly that they've seen better acting in porno movies. For once it's REALLY TRUE. No person in this movie ever really emotes or gives the sense that what they are doing (saving the world?) really matters. Love relationships between characters seem strange and cold, people are introduced in one scene as being important and are never seen again in the movie. The main character actually disappears for 14 min. leaving all the others to fend for themselves. They even manage to introduce a character at the very end of the third act who has never been mentioned, or even alluded to, in the movie. Being part two of a three part trilogy was rough on this movie and the viewers. At the end of the first Matrix all is tied up. Neo is "The One" and about to board the Pain Train set for all points in the Matrix. All's well that ends well, right? $$$ not exactly. Neo's role in this movie is much less than the all-powerful One we were lead to believe. He's more of the One-half. He can get into long fight sequences but can't determine if he really has free will or is pre-destined to do everything he's doing. Everything about this movie was bad. The acting was sub-standard, the fight scenes were boring and uninspiried and the cliff-hanger ending was worse than most soap operas. I really expected to hear "Bum-bum-BUMMM!!!" at the end. Then the trailer for M3 takes what little wind the ending has (He makes it out of the coma!). So why go see a bad movie? I saw the first one in the theater, was sucked in by the spectacle of it all and gave it an unsure thumbs-up. I rented it, watched it alone and only then did I realize what a bad movie it was. Of course maybe I'm just doing this to be contrary, but I really think this movie sucked. For once, words fail me. I knew it was going to be bad, but I tried and tried to view it objectivly and still I was left loathing the movie. I hate, hate, HATE this movie. I can't wait to see how god-awful the next one is. From here on out it's all just morbid curiosity.

"Knight Life" is a skewed modern take on the King Arthur legend. Take the King put him in modern NYC and watch the fish out of water hilarity ensue. Good but not great. A solid 'B.' "Good Omens" features two things I hate. The cover features the words 'a novel' and two it's a co-written book. Another 'B.' I did smile, smirk even... but laugh out loud? Nope. Humor is hard when put in the mold of the written word.

Halloweenie Oh, yes. The day is almost upon us. Given my background in folklore (I took a few classes, hardly enough to qualify me as an expert. But close enough for funk, I say) I wanted to pass on some good ol' spooooky stories. All of them true. All of them involving me. Mostly because I can't write about anything else... When I was in seventh grade I was finally allowed to go trick-or-treating on my own. Given my new found freedom the night hardly seemed long enough, but in hindsight it seemed to go on forever. Everything happened in one night. About five or six of my friends and I set out for the uncharted territories east of our old elementary school. By the end of the night we had been jumped by some other guys from our junior high (they wanted candy, but didn't want to work for it) and we had pillowcases full of loot. In my 12 years on the planet I had never seen such a haul. But I digress. The weather was what you typically expect from October. Not chilly enough to be cold, but cold enough so that smells carried for miles ( Candles in pumpkins, dead leaves, etc.). Half the group had gone home leaving me and two of my cohorts to travel down a dark street. As we meandered down the street a figure came around the bend. He was taller than any man I had ever seen before and dressed as some kind of hooded monk. Clothed in a brown robe and sandals (yes, sandals) he carried a long staff topped with a crucifix. But no candy. Not even an apple with a razor blade in it or any of the other stuff you would expect a psycho to carry. The closer he got to us was directly proportional to how scared we got. By the time he stood directly in front of us we realized that we could not see his face. It was covered mostly by his hood and some kind of dime store mask. But that wasn't important. He stopped. We stopped. And there we stood. Some one said "hey" or "what up" to him. He just moaned or grunted. And then silence. Then he shuffled past us. We watched him walk down the street and turn at the corner. Then we ran like hell. No one was ever going to believe this.

Gather 'round young ones... I'm gonna tell you all about a little hole in the wall called the Locker Room Saloon. I'll preface the story with the supposition that everyone knows Flint, Michigan is the armpit of the state. Nothing Michael Moore can say, or do, will ever change this. Now, by making Flint the armpit we can extrapolate that The Locker Room (located right here in Utica, MI) would be some kind of festering pimple on the back of the state. That being said, The Locker Room is a charming local tradition of the tri-county area where young and old gather to bang on things with sticks. Yes, a bar where drunk folk are encouraged to be wacky and drum on anything and everything. The Locker Room experience unfolds as such. Pay a $5 cover to get through the door and stand in line. You are then presented with one (1) playing card and two (2) "drum sticks." I use the quotes because the sticks are actually doll rods, roughly the same size of drum sticks. Anyways. You're ordered to get your fist drink at the bar and then mingle. I should have put mingle in quotes because you're really standing shoulder to shoulder with some dude that reeks of 'Drakar' and puts turtle wax in his hair and some woman who out weighs me by at least 50 pounds. Nothing against her, I'm a skinny white man so it's not hard to be larger than me. You're then assigned a section. Red, blue, yellow, left side of bar or right side of bar. The section also comes with a waiter bearing a clever nom de guerre like "Tackleberry," "Beaker," or even, "Cooter." Then there's the DJ. Imagine every shitty wedding DJ that you've ever come across, okay? Now, when these men eventually hang themselves in a closet somewhere or drink anti-freeze their damned souls are funneled into this one being of pure evil. Yes, a man so evil that he will pick you out of a crowd and order you to have a good time by leading the rest or the bar in the "Hustle" or "Chicken dance." He also serves to pit different sides of the bar against another in shouting matches...only to declare that everyone's a winner so the "prize" of dollar shooters goes to all. So that's the basic premise. People stand on furniture and bang on things with sticks. (An aside, I once heard that the sticks were outlawed for a time because a fight broke out and someone was stabbed with one. I'm not stating this as the Bible truth, only a colorful urban legend. Way better than the murder house.) I almost forgot about the playing cards! The playing card that you're given when entering, in theory, has a double that's given to a member of the opposite sex. So, you could hook-up with somebody solely on the basis that "we're both 'sixes'!" This is how my parents met. The Locker Room is a hive of scum and villainy, the likes of which I haven't seen since the Mos Eisley cantina in Star Wars . It's small, cramped, stinky and, worst of all, my Budweiser was warm. It's not fun at all. How this place has been open for twenty-plus years escapes me. It honestly does. How did I wind up there? Well, I do have some kind of genetic memory that the place is a shit-hole and should be avoided at all costs. But what can I say? My curiosity got the best of me. Now I know for sure that the place is a shit-hole. Mystery solved. What kind of playing card did I get? Ace of Hearts. No lie.

Unlike most of the other nonfoolish holidays, the history of April Fool's Day, sometimes called All Fool's Day, is not totally clear. There really wasn't a "first April Fool's Day" that can be pinpointed on the calendar. Some believe it sort of evolved simultaneously in several cultures at the same time, from celebrations involving the first day of spring. The closest point in time that can be identified as the beginning of this tradition was in 1582, in France. Prior to that year, the new year was celebrated for eight days, beginning on March 25. The celebration culminated on April 1. With the reform of the calendar under Charles IX, the Gregorian Calendar was introduced, and New Year's Day was moved to January 1. However, communications being what they were in the days when news traveled by foot, many people did not receive the news for several years. Others, the more obstinate crowd, refused to accept the new calendar and continued to celebrate the new year on April 1. These backward folk were labeled as "fools" by the general populace. They were subject to some ridicule, and were often sent on "fools errands" or were made the butt of other practical jokes. This harassment evolved, over time, into a tradition of prank-playing on the first day of April. The tradition eventually spread to England and Scotland in the eighteenth century. It was later introduced to the American colonies of both the English and French. April Fool's Day thus developed into an international fun fest, so to speak, with different nationalities specializing in their own brand of humor at the expense of their friends and families. If you believe I wrote that....APRIL FOOLS! No, seriously....it's all true.

I rolled in this morning at exactly 5:10 a.m. Screaming east down M-59 I watched the sky turn from a deep indigo to a hazy pink. Just me and my car trying to make it to bed before the sun came up. I had solidly split my time between trying to stay awake and pointless introspection. Let me tell you, being alone in a car (in the dark)is quite conducive to psychological self-examination. Anyways, back to the previous six hours. How did I spend my evening? Drinking? No (well, maybe a little bit). Debauchery? Hardly. Drugs? Never. I spent the evening being cross-examined by two of my best friends and re-hashing recent events in my life. Neither of these things are particularly therapeutic nor helpful. Nobody knows how to turn the screws like your friends. Of course this only took up a fair portion of the night. But what we spoke of brewed in the back of my mind (like it wasn't brewing before this) until the long car ride home. Once again, I made it home in one piece. The birds had already started singing and night was slowly giving way to day. I got in bed ready to sleep but unable to. I tossed and turned for awhile and eventually I fell asleep... ...Only to be awakened by my asshole neighbor mowing his lawn three hours later.
It's a Friday night and this is the most sober I've been in days. I know my life has flown off the tracks a bit...but this is almost too much to bear.

That's right it's day number 9,125. 219,000 hours, 13,140,000 minutes and 788,400,000 seconds...and I feel every bit of it. I'm 25 today. Half way to fifty. One quarter of a century. There's no denying it, I am solidly in my mid-twenties. A milestone, I'm told. So am I supposed to grow up now? I'm not one to freak out about getting older...I'm just growing into my "old soul." I guess I'm just a perpetual optimist, this year will be better than the last year. Or maybe I'm just in perpetual denial. The headline of this post reminds me of a song I once heard from a musical I've never seen. Maybe I'll take in some culture this year. Maybe I'll finish writing that play this year. Maybe I've grown out of procrastinating. Maybe, maybe, maybe. Who wants a spanking? I still don't know where I'm going, but I can't help but look forward to the future. The immediate future includes a trip to my favorite pub tonight. I have it on good authority that beer does not taste as good anywhere else. I tend to agree. The far future is hard to define, always is. Here's a prediction: Minor/major victories, crushing defeats, laughter, love, loss, family, friends and all the other cliche bullshit. You know why things become cliche, don't you? Because they're true. That's life. ....and I feel every bit of it.
